Was there that arrangement with the college and the county council?
There was.
Is it like a service level agreement?
There's a service level agreement with Pembrokeshire County Council.
When I came here, we used to get a fixed sum of money
for however many people came for the service.
Which I think is possibly why we had more bodies here.
After I'd been here for about two years,
they decided to change the model and the way that they did it,
and we were funded per participant per day.
And if they were absent for any reason, we received half a fee.
And that carried on for about four years,
and several of us got together and said, several providers got together and said,
This doesn't pay its way.
We can't provide a service at that sort of level.
So we had an uplift to about £28 a day, but no fee for absences.
Which was a bit annoying because we're geared up for them,
the staff are still here, everything is still here.
And then that carried on all the way until last year.
We didn't get another uplift until last year.
And even now, it's only just covering the staff.
It doesn't cover any expenditure for running the place.
Which is why we've had to go down the commercial route.
Yes, and perhaps we'll loop around to that in a minute.
We also have the agreement, the third party agreement with Pembrokeshire College.
And we're funded via the college by Welsh Government for education.
When I first came here, the education side of things was in a very sorry state.
We were a centre in our own rights for city and guilds,
but we were in special measures.
There wasn't anybody who was here to teach it properly.
And the way education is delivered has moved on faster than we as an organisation had moved on.
An advisor came in from Pembrokeshire College and worked with myself and Louise.
And we developed courses to suit what we were doing with city and guilds,
with evidence-based files for each student.
And within a year, we were back to good to excellent with city and guilds.
So that was quite an achievement.
And then during that time, Pembrokeshire College funded me to do a delivering learning programme.
I did a course for delivering learning at the college.
So I did that just to give me a base background in education, how to deliver a session,
what evidence was required and what was acceptable evidence to prove that somebody had achieved at a certain level.
And then following on from that, the college very kindly funded me to do a P-set,
which is a PGCE in effect for post-16 education.
I'm not a graduate, so I can't say it's a PGCE even though it's exactly the same course.
So I did that for two years and passed that in 2014.
So that's the full teaching qualification.
That's right, yeah.
I mean, I've done very little in the way of teaching since then
because of the way this job has evolved and changed so much.
But I've got the base understanding and the knowledge to be able to manage whoever is underneath me doing that.
And yes, to supervise and recognise what's needed.
Yeah, absolutely.
Yeah, I mean, I've been involved now probably about 10 years, I think.

So, just to go back to those old City and Guilds units then, we've said they were horticulture,
so for somebody coming to this that knows nothing about the garden, what would they practically have been doing,
what were they being assessed on day to day?
Oh, we had various things from weeding, there was a unit on hoeing, there was one on mowing,
there was one on seed planting, taking cuttings, potting on.
So essentially people were doing the gardening day in, day out as they came and being assessed on what was going on.
Yes, you didn't have to, with the City and Guilds ones, the units that we're doing now and units with the Goryd and units we did with ABC,
they actually have to produce a piece of work or evidence piece of work of them doing something and they had to,
they might have to write a paragraph or discuss something.
Back then you had your criteria, for example, fill your pot with compost and you gave them a score, one, two, three and four.
So the first time they did it they might get a one, the next time they did it they might get a two and then they might get a four.
When they've got a four you sign them as achieved that unit, but we didn't have to have photographic evidence,
they didn't have to be, that's all changed drastically now, that's all changed drastically.

And you work, well, I mean, I remember you saying, you know, I know you still work with the forum, don't you?
We have a day opportunities providers forum where we all get together every two months to air various things and sort of keep in the loop, if you like.
But I'm also on the learning disability partnership board, which is a board run by Pembrokeshire County Council.
And on that board we have representatives from health, from social care, from housing, from transport, from day services and so on.
And from carers. So it's a really broad range.
And that board has actually developed the Pembrokeshire learning disability strategy, which is, I think it's available on Pembrokeshire County Council's website.
And that's obviously a moving document and it's ongoing. It's been going about four years now.
And, you know, there are several actions that have been completed already on that and things are moving forward now to do the next strategy, which will take us for another three years.
So do you feel in that way there is more structure and some support in that way, even if not so much monetary support? Is there more recognition, do you think, of the work?
Yes and no. Yes and no. I think they're going through a process at the moment called transforming day opportunities in Pembrokeshire.
They're looking to make it a more person-centred service and they're looking at putting everybody's services, everything that's available,
from rock climbing on a Tuesday evening to a day service here on a leisure app.
So people will book onto it like they will only have access to what they have been funded for, but they will be able to book onto things as you would book onto a fitness class at the leisure centre.
We've had several discussions already. It's in its very baby stages at the moment. I don't quite know how that's going to work with...
It wouldn't work if somebody signed on for a six-week block with us. You know, we need more of a commitment than that because it's just going to get very, very complicated if we start doing short-term placements like that.
But I think they're aware of that. They're talking to all of the service providers and they've all said the same as me.
The people who do a day service like we do have said the same as me. That won't work. That's great if they want to go rock climbing on a Tuesday evening, but it doesn't really work for this.
So that will have to be thought about quite carefully.
